meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny, folks! I'm here to bring you the lowdown on Wizardry: Proving Grounds of the Mad Overlord, a remake that's got everyone talking (except for maybe my mom, she's still not a fan of video games). As someone who's all about having fun with games (and also making fun of myself and other critics), I'm excited to dive into this retro revival.

Now, let me tell you what the other folks are saying. Hardcore Gamer thinks it's "a solid choice" for old-school RPG enthusiasts, but might be a bit too punishing for newbies. IGN Italia just calls it a "competent remake" that's way too faithful to the original. The Games Machine praises Digital Eclipse for breathing life into classics, but says Wizardry is now a bit limited in its mechanics and pace. Multiplayer.it thinks it's great, but maybe a bit too hard for modern audiences. And SECTOR.sk gives it a lukewarm review, saying it's a pleasant reminder of the original game, but with less convincing gameplay.

Me? I'm just here to tell you that Wizardry is a blast from the past – literally! You get to explore dungeons, fight monsters, and make decisions that'll determine your character's fate. It's like playing an old-school RPG, but with modern graphics and controls (which, let me tell you, are still a bit wonky at times). The game has got some serious nostalgic value, and I can see why fans of the original would love it.

But what about new players? Well, be warned: Wizardry is NOT for the faint of heart. It's got a steep learning curve, and those pesky monsters will take you down if you're not careful (I mean, who doesn't love a good challenge, right?). However, if you're up for it, the game rewards strategy and patience – just like old-school RPGs used to.

So, what's my verdict? Well, I'm not going to give it a score or anything fancy like that. Instead, I'll just say this: Wizardry is a great remake that'll transport you back in time (or at least, make you feel like you're playing an old-school RPG). If you're a fan of the genre, you owe it to yourself to check it out.

And if you're not? Well, let's just say it might be worth giving it a shot – for the sheer nostalgia factor alone! After all, as they say in the review biz: "If it ain't broke, don't fix it... unless you're Digital Eclipse, and then you can remake it and make it even more awesome!"
